Paul Olefsky, distinguished
American cellist, will appear
this Sunday at 8:30 P.M. hi
Shrivel. Hall when the New
Chamber Orchestra makes its
debut under the direction of

The concert, sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins Chamber Music
Society, will mark the first public performance by the newly
formed orchestra, which was
organized specifically to perform works which are new to
Baltimore concert audiences and
to develop new audiences for
chamber music.
Featured in their program will
be the first Baltimore performances of two Vivaldi concerti, in
C minor and in D major, Leone
Sinigaglia's "Two Characteristic
Pieces," and "Tarantella" by Alfonzo Castoldi. The concert will
also include a, world premiere
of Angelo Gatto's "Vecchi Tempi" and the rarely performed
"Grand Concerto" by G. F. Handel.

Angelo Gatto, Music Director

Choral Society
A Johns Hopkins Choral Society is now being formed.
Under the direction of Nelson
Swegler, the organization has as
its primary goal the performance of large choral masterworks with orchestra accompaniment, using the finest of local
professional soloists.
This spring the Choral Society
will present Arthur Honegger's
"King David" with members of
the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. The Society is open to
members of the Johns Hopkins
Institutions, students, faculty,
administration, hospital staff,
nurses and wives. Rehearsals are
scheduled for Tuesday evenings
from 8:15 P.M. to 10:00 P.M.,
with the initial meeting on
Tuesday, January 11th at Levering Hall, Homewood.
Applicants should have a
voice suitable for chorus work
and should be able to read
music. For further information
contact the Director of Student
Music, Shriver Hall, Homewood.

State of Union
Cummings and Peabody will
analyze the President's Stateof-the-Union address as the
most important guidelines offered Congress in its opening
weeks. President Johnson's annual message is slated for delivery prior to the second television appearance of the two
Hopkins professors on January
16.
Dr. Cummings, an expert in
American political parties, will
offer some predictions about the
number of seats that may be lost
to the Republicans in the 1966
elections.
In a recently published book,
New Perspective on the House of
Representatives, Peabody and
Cummings co-authored a chapter on the 1961 enlargement of
the House Rules Committee.
Cummings completed his graduate study at Harvard, and Peabody earned the Ph.D. at Stanford University.

Dr. Abel Wolman, professor
emeritus of the Johns Hopkins
University, has been appointed
chairman of the Scientists and
Engineers Committee of the
Maryland Science Center building fund. Dr. Wolman said he
took the appointment "to interest professionals in the science
field in the Maryland Academy
as well as enticing them to contribute to the campaign."
A goal of $6,000,000 has been
set and the State of Maryland
is expected to contribute about
a third of this. Dr. Wolman feels
that the Baltimore area will be
greatly benefited by the new
Science Center which is to be
located in the New Harbor renewal area. Construction is
scheduled to begin early in 1967.
"The Maryland Academy of
Sciences will use the building to
expand the many educational
programs they now offer to
school children and adults," Dr.
Wolman stated. Currently, the
Academy is housed in the Enoch
Pratt Library. •
Also in the works for Dr.
Wolman is membership on a
Public Health Service corn-

mittee that will review the policy of quarantine in this country. Methods now used will be
investigated to decide whether
they are sufficient to insure proteetion against communicable
diseases.
Dr. Wolman received his B.E.
S. in 1915 and his Ph.D. in 1937
from Hopkins. He was professor
of Sanitary Engineering from
1937-1962, and, over the years
has been active with many
groups in and out of the field
of Sanitary Engineering. Among
these positions are member of
the Atomic Energy Commission
1947-1960, member of the Na-

tional Academy of Sciences, and
member of the Maryland Water
Study Commission. Dr. Wolman
has also written or edited three
books in the Sanitary Engineering field.

"What To Take" En Route: '66
Scientists have mange(' to pack more into a pill
than ever before, opening up a whole new world of
cures, catchalls, moods and in general, all forms of
rehabilitation and inducement. The expanded content.,
HOW possible in a pill has made this improved instrument in medicine equally important as a remedy and
as a route to introducing new modes of behavior, cures
to natural ills, and avenues to many inside-out states
of mind. Witlaut a doubt, advances in capsule(' medicine have gone far beyond the pill-box practitioners of a
sentury ago.
The newest tablet is reported to extend one's capacity for memory, by calling forth long-forgotten facts.
This new pill was a major topic at the session of American Association for the Advancement of Science at the
University of California, and brings to the fore an
Immense field of potential discovery along with an even
larger field of questions on what can be legitimately acoomplished through oral medicine.
Years ago, the treatment for Syphilis, a laborious
administering of mercurial ointment, as painful for the
applier as for the applicant, led to the quip: one night
with Venus and die rest of your life with Mercury. The
recent capsuling of whatever it is that abates this illness, has given rise to this revision: one night with
Venus, three weeks with Penicillin, and you're reclassified 1A. Of course, if Venus is smart, she will also have
sonic pills along for her own purposes; all of which is
only to give testament that inhibitions as well as prohibtions can be capsuled.
This new idea of pilling memory leads the imagination to Conjecture an endless market for pills, pharmaceutical, political, social and otherwise, which could
change the face of the earth. If memory can be canned,
so can nourishment, good will and persuasion. We envision a prescribed dose for all the starving people in
the world with the prospect that all poor and persecuted
people will soon be properly pilled to swallow their
sorrows away. And why can't there be pills for all bad
boys to make them good, or pills for all good girls to
make them bad, for communistic aggressors to make
diem capitalistic pigs, and so it goes.
The interest at Hopkins, at the end of the semester
Is concerned more with local applications. Of all the
pills, the memory pill, whose promise of alleviating the
burden of the coming round of examinations, is more
likely to bear immediate fruit. Its acceptance would be
immediate, but the consequence would be grave.
The problem lies in the monitoring of its use,
in dispensing of measured amounts, in conforming to
official policy on how far back our memory should he
allowed to go. The Honor Commission will have to have
a hand in this for they will have to decide the dosage
in order to equalize the effect throughout the school.
There will be violators, in course, who will easily corner
the market on memory; there will arise the real
"throat" who packs and pushes baking soda off for all
forms of mental persuasion. The Commission would
shortly he obligated to investigate, confiscate, and
organize a pill police force to protect the pill-polluted
community. Aside from stepping, once more, on the
honor commission's toes, these pills would surely enhance the general good.
And speaking of the general good an inventive
News-Letter reporter suggested that one would find
some day, in the office of the President, a stock of such
medication as vials of well-placed-authority, enlightened
discipline, little pills for political acumen, among just a
few others.
The News-Letter, in the hest of faith, prescribes
for the New Year, a pill instead of a resolution, much
easier to swallow and, as we have pointed out, guaranteed to make die desirable entirely possible. We do not
pretend to be the campus pharmacist, but do enjoy pretending. Our efforts, we feel, allow for a peculiarly
accurate evaluation of existing illnesses, and have worth,
consequently, in both fact arid fancy.

outside world. One must leave
the confines of the ivy covered
halls to learn what, if anything,
is happening in the outside
world. The big news stories, New
York, Saigon, Atlanta, Green
Bay, somehow manage to penetrate, but the truly meaningful
happenings outside the grassy
lawns of Homewood escape the
eye of the average Hoppie.

Scott Stick Coach of Year;
Mallonee Soccer All-Am.
Hopkins mentor Bob Scott
was selected Lacrosse Coach of
the Year in a United States Lapoll
of
Association
crosse
coaches and sportswriters last
week.
This is the first time that
Scott, a June '52 graduate of
Hopkins, has won the award,
which has been presented annually since 1959 in memory of
Morris Touchstone of West
Point. Although losing to Navy
and Mt. Washington, Scott
coached the Jays to a 9-2 '65
season which included wins over
vaunted Army and Maryland.
His composite record since
taking over the coaching reigns
here in 1954 is 76-32-1. Collegiately he is 76-22-1. He has garnered two national championships plus one unbeaten—untied
year when his contingent was
not elected to the title.
In 1952 Scott was captain of
the Hopkins varsity stick team,
co-captain of the North-South
team, and an honorable mention
All-America.
Dr. William Kelso Morrill was
Scott's coach here. As a sophomore Scott and Wilson Fewster,
now Hopkins football coach,
were teammates. Two years later
Fewster was in a coaching position, coaching Scott.
Scott credited Assistant coach
Henry Ciccarone and Fewster,
who took care of scouting, with
making his job "easier."
Senior Lucky Mallonee, already holding first-team All

America lacrosse honors, was
picked to the '65 All America
soccer contingent Wednesday by
a poll of coaches and referees.
For the smooth-running halfback, this was a return to AllAmerica soccer ranking after a
one-year absence. He was named
honorable-mention All America
as a soplunore but missed the
standings last season.
All South

was selected
first-team
All
South and second-team All

lacrosse. The season before he
was named to the third team.
Mallonee graduated from Baltimore's Park School, where he
was coached by Joe Seivold, former All America from Washington College. While at Park, he
was named to MSA basketball,
soccer, and lacrosse teams.
Not First

to turn the trick of making two
different All-America teams this
year. End Michael Oidick was
named honorable-mention Little

third-team All America in lacrosse.

win national, honors in both
lacrosse and soccer in a single
year was Buzzy Budnitz in 1953.

Dr. Abel Wolman, professor
emeritus of the Johns Hopkins
University, has been appointed
chairman of the Scientists and
Engineers Committee of the
Maryland Science Center building fund. Dr. Wolman said he
took the appointment "to interest professionals in the science
field in the Maryland Academy
as well as enticing them to contribute to the campaign."
A goal of $6,000,000 has been
set and the State of Maryland
is expected to contribute about
a third of this. Dr. Wolman feels
that the Baltimore area will be
greatly benefited by the new
Science Center which is to be
located in the New Harbor renewal area. Construction is
scheduled to begin early in 1967.
"The Maryland Academy of
Sciences will use the building to
expand the many educational
programs they now offer to
school children and adults," Dr.
Wolman stated. Currently, the
Academy is housed in the Enoch
Pratt Library. •
Also in the works for Dr.
Wolman is membership on a
Public Health Service corn-

mittee that will review the policy of quarantine in this country. Methods now used will be
investigated to decide whether
they are sufficient to insure proteetion against communicable
diseases.
Dr. Wolman received his B.E.
S. in 1915 and his Ph.D. in 1937
from Hopkins. He was professor
of Sanitary Engineering from
1937-1962, and, over the years
has been active with many
groups in and out of the field
of Sanitary Engineering. Among
these positions are member of
the Atomic Energy Commission
1947-1960, member of the Na-

tional Academy of Sciences, and
member of the Maryland Water
Study Commission. Dr. Wolman
has also written or edited three
books in the Sanitary Engineering field.

"What To Take" En Route: '66
Scientists have mange(' to pack more into a pill
than ever before, opening up a whole new world of
cures, catchalls, moods and in general, all forms of
rehabilitation and inducement. The expanded content.,
HOW possible in a pill has made this improved instrument in medicine equally important as a remedy and
as a route to introducing new modes of behavior, cures
to natural ills, and avenues to many inside-out states
of mind. Witlaut a doubt, advances in capsule(' medicine have gone far beyond the pill-box practitioners of a
sentury ago.
The newest tablet is reported to extend one's capacity for memory, by calling forth long-forgotten facts.
This new pill was a major topic at the session of American Association for the Advancement of Science at the
University of California, and brings to the fore an
Immense field of potential discovery along with an even
larger field of questions on what can be legitimately acoomplished through oral medicine.
Years ago, the treatment for Syphilis, a laborious
administering of mercurial ointment, as painful for the
applier as for the applicant, led to the quip: one night
with Venus and die rest of your life with Mercury. The
recent capsuling of whatever it is that abates this illness, has given rise to this revision: one night with
Venus, three weeks with Penicillin, and you're reclassified 1A. Of course, if Venus is smart, she will also have
sonic pills along for her own purposes; all of which is
only to give testament that inhibitions as well as prohibtions can be capsuled.
This new idea of pilling memory leads the imagination to Conjecture an endless market for pills, pharmaceutical, political, social and otherwise, which could
change the face of the earth. If memory can be canned,
so can nourishment, good will and persuasion. We envision a prescribed dose for all the starving people in
the world with the prospect that all poor and persecuted
people will soon be properly pilled to swallow their
sorrows away. And why can't there be pills for all bad
boys to make them good, or pills for all good girls to
make them bad, for communistic aggressors to make
diem capitalistic pigs, and so it goes.
The interest at Hopkins, at the end of the semester
Is concerned more with local applications. Of all the
pills, the memory pill, whose promise of alleviating the
burden of the coming round of examinations, is more
likely to bear immediate fruit. Its acceptance would be
immediate, but the consequence would be grave.
The problem lies in the monitoring of its use,
in dispensing of measured amounts, in conforming to
official policy on how far back our memory should he
allowed to go. The Honor Commission will have to have
a hand in this for they will have to decide the dosage
in order to equalize the effect throughout the school.
There will be violators, in course, who will easily corner
the market on memory; there will arise the real
"throat" who packs and pushes baking soda off for all
forms of mental persuasion. The Commission would
shortly he obligated to investigate, confiscate, and
organize a pill police force to protect the pill-polluted
community. Aside from stepping, once more, on the
honor commission's toes, these pills would surely enhance the general good.
And speaking of the general good an inventive
News-Letter reporter suggested that one would find
some day, in the office of the President, a stock of such
medication as vials of well-placed-authority, enlightened
discipline, little pills for political acumen, among just a
few others.
The News-Letter, in the hest of faith, prescribes
for the New Year, a pill instead of a resolution, much
easier to swallow and, as we have pointed out, guaranteed to make die desirable entirely possible. We do not
pretend to be the campus pharmacist, but do enjoy pretending. Our efforts, we feel, allow for a peculiarly
accurate evaluation of existing illnesses, and have worth,
consequently, in both fact arid fancy.

nobody Is dejected.

By MARSHALL PAUL
There'll be no room for tender
old loyalties when Hopkins and
Western Maryland tangle in the
varsity wrestling team's home
opener Wednesday night.
Coaching the Jays is Dave
Blizzard, who mentored the Terror matmen last season. On the
other side of the ring is Hopkins' coach of a-year-ago &tin
Case, who is running the Western Maryland aggregation now.
The visitors have five lettermen returning. Standouts are
King Hill (123); Gary Kulick, a
191 pounder; and Ray Schnertzler (160).
The matmen, who visit Haverford tomorrow, lost to Lebanon
21-10 just before vacation. They
won two matches and tied one.
Heading the Jays' effort was 137
pounder Joe Griggs, who came
from behind in the third period
of his match to win 7-6.
Brad Keller (160) notched
their only other victory. He also
game from behind. Down 4-3 he
got a quick reversal and then
pinned Joe Torre with a reverse
sradle.

Scott Stick Coach of Year;
Mallonee Soccer All-Am.
Hopkins mentor Bob Scott
was selected Lacrosse Coach of
the Year in a United States Lapoll
of
Association
crosse
coaches and sportswriters last
week.
This is the first time that
Scott, a June '52 graduate of
Hopkins, has won the award,
which has been presented annually since 1959 in memory of
Morris Touchstone of West
Point. Although losing to Navy
and Mt. Washington, Scott
coached the Jays to a 9-2 '65
season which included wins over
vaunted Army and Maryland.
His composite record since
taking over the coaching reigns
here in 1954 is 76-32-1. Collegiately he is 76-22-1. He has garnered two national championships plus one unbeaten—untied
year when his contingent was
not elected to the title.
In 1952 Scott was captain of
the Hopkins varsity stick team,
co-captain of the North-South
team, and an honorable mention
All-America.
Dr. William Kelso Morrill was
Scott's coach here. As a sophomore Scott and Wilson Fewster,
now Hopkins football coach,
were teammates. Two years later
Fewster was in a coaching position, coaching Scott.
Scott credited Assistant coach
Henry Ciccarone and Fewster,
who took care of scouting, with
making his job "easier."
Senior Lucky Mallonee, already holding first-team All

America lacrosse honors, was
picked to the '65 All America
soccer contingent Wednesday by
a poll of coaches and referees.
For the smooth-running halfback, this was a return to AllAmerica soccer ranking after a
one-year absence. He was named
honorable-mention All America
as a soplunore but missed the
standings last season.
All South
Earlier last month, Mallonee
was selected
first-team
All
South and second-team All
Mason-Dixon Conference. As a
midfielder, he worked his way
to first team All America in
lacrosse. The season before he
was named to the third team.
Mallonee graduated from Baltimore's Park School, where he
was coached by Joe Seivold, former All America from Washington College. While at Park, he
was named to MSA basketball,
soccer, and lacrosse teams.
Not First
Mallonee was not the first Jay
_

to turn the trick of making two
different All-America teams this
year. End Michael Oidick was
named honorable-mention Little
All America In football and was
third-team All America in lacrosse.
The last Hopkins athlete to
win national, honors in both
lacrosse and soccer in a single
year was Buzzy Budnitz in 1953.
